0.32.text:
Hi everybody. I haven't made a video in a
little while, because things have been a bit

5.92.text:
mad lately. I've just moved to London, so
there's obviously been a lot of upheaval involved

11.59.text:
in that, a lot of things to sort out. But
we're settling in nicely now, we're getting

15.16.text:
the hang of things, we've got a few things
that we need done. Like I say, there's still

19.84.text: plenty to do, but we're happy now, we're comfortable.

23.42.text:
And I've also joined a social club up here,
so that's given me a chance to get out and

26.75.text:
about and meet some new people. So I've done
things like walking round Kensington Gardens,

31.22.text:
I've played Cards Against Humanity, I've been
to a quiz night, I've got a curry night coming

35.80.text:
up, I've got escape rooms coming up, and various
other bits and pieces, there's quite a lot.

40.60.text:
So it's been really good to just meet some
new people, make some new acquaintances. That's

47.11.text: really helped me to settle in and just have a good time and just, like I say, get out and about.

51.76.text:
But the reason for this video is that I've
been tagged by the wonderful Emily Davison

56.62.text:
over at Fashioneyesta - hello! - who does
a lot of videos about disability, as well

63.81.text:
as beauty and fashion. So there's something
in there for everyone, do go and check her

68.32.text:
out, and her blog, and her Twitter, and her
Instagram, and her Audioboom, she's everywhere.

72.36.text:
She does a wonderful job, so yeah, do go and
check her out, I'll link her down below.

76.79.text:
Emily has tagged me to do the Visually Impaired
Persons Tag - the VIP Tag - which was originally

82.83.text:
created by Chatty Chelby, who I'll also link
down below, and whose channel I also recommend

87.19.text:
you subscribe to. She also talks about disability
and her visual impairment and all the stuff

91.26.text:
she gets up to, so that's really good to
watch. So yeah, check her out as well.

95.03.text: So yeah, thank you to Emily for tagging me, and thank you to Chelby for creating the tag in the first place.

100.69.text:
I did do this tag last year in my written
blog, over at welleyenever.com, but that was

109.21.text:
pretty much a year ago. It was back in February
when I checked the date, so that's soon gone.

113.82.text:
So these answers might be slightly different,
it might give you a more rounded view if you

119.04.text:
read that in conjunction with watching this.
I'm not gonna try and make it identical, but

122.89.text:
there will be some overlap, some crossover,
as is inevitable. So yeah, I hope you find

129.74.text:
it interesting, and let's get on with the
questions.

132.68.text:
What medical condition caused you to be blind
or visually impaired?

136.63.text:
Well I have Aniridia and Nystagmus. I've done
videos on each of those, which I'll link to.

143.78.text:
But in summary, Aniridia basically means I
don't have an iris in my eye. And the iris

148.44.text:
controls the size of the pupil, to determine
how much light comes in and out of my eye.

154.16.text:
So when it's really dark, the pupil should
expand to let in as much light as possible,

158.85.text:
and when it's really bright, the pupil should
shrink, so that less light comes in. But because

163.80.text:
it doesn't do that, I'm much more sensitive
to glare, more so than other people would

169.68.text:
be, and I find it a bit trickier to adjust
to seeing in the dark. I don't do too badly,

177.57.text:
And then Nystagmus basically means that my
eyes shake or wobble involuntarily all the

182.60.text:
time. I don't notice it - like Aniridia, I've
always had this, so my brain's adapted to

189.65.text:
it. But it does mean I can't read things at
a distance, because I can't get the focus

194.84.text:
on it for long enough, and I have to have
things close up to read them, and even then

199.63.text:
it can be a bit of a strain to read for very
long, because I've got to focus quite intently

205.17.text: to read text for a while.

207.10.text:
One of the adaptations that I use, on computers
and on my phone, is that I invert the colours

214.54.text:
on the screen. So that means I have white
text on a black background, which is the opposite

221.17.text:
to what most people have. And that means I
don't get the glare off the screen, and it's

226.47.text:
really good contrast text for me, so that
I can read it much more comfortably and easily,

231.96.text:
so I can read for a bit longer. So that really
helps a great deal, it makes a huge difference.

238.08.text:
I've had both of those conditions since birth,
so as far as I'm concerned my condition is

243.15.text:
normal, and my brain has adapted to them.
I mean, I know my vision isn't normal, but

248.76.text:
I don't know what normal is like, so I don't
feel like I've lost anything, I don't feel

252.78.text:
that I'm missing anything, even though I know
I am, if that makes sense. This just seems

257.62.text:
normal to me, this is everyday to me, so I
don't have a problem with it. I've always

262.49.text:
just lived with it and adapted to it, and
it's not stopped me doing things I want to

266.78.text: do. So yeah, I'm happy and comfortable.

269.85.text:
Question 2 - In three words, describe your
vision.

272.40.text:
Well I would say short, light-sensitive. Because
I am short-sighted. Although I can see things

279.75.text:
at a distance, I can't see the detail. So
I can't read signs at a distance. So if I'm

284.29.text:
using the Tube or the buses, I'll use a little
telescope called a monocular that I can read

288.76.text:
things in the distance with. And then light-sensitive,
as I've just said when explaining Aniridia,

295.41.text: I'm very sensitive to bright sunlight.

298.04.text:
And even when the sun isn't directly out,
it may be glaring off the clouds, or off buildings,

304.60.text:
or something like that, or off raindrops that
have recently fallen, I can be quite sensitive

309.15.text:
to that. Some days are better than others,
but when I'm having a particularly bad day,

314.00.text: yes It can be quite irritating.

315.50.text:
So I do wear sunglasses quite a lot. Even
when it's cloudy, you'll see me wearing sunglasses

319.98.text:
sometimes. So, yeah... but like I say, it's
just something I've got used to, the sunglasses

327.13.text:
really help, so that makes things easier when
I'm outdoors, as does using the monocular.

331.92.text:
So I've just found ways to adapt and get round
things as best I can.

335.84.text:
Question 3 - What is the hardest thing to
do being blind or visually impaired?

340.74.text:
I would say meeting and interacting with other
people can be quite hard sometimes, especially

346.34.text:
regularly sighted people. Because obviously
meeting with people who are also visually

350.20.text:
impaired, they automatically understand you
and they know how to interact with you. Interacting

359.49.text:
with normally sighted people can be hard when
they don't really know you to begin with.

363.24.text:
You know, if you're going to meet someone
somewhere, they might say meet in a pub or

368.81.text:
something, and you're kind of looking around
trying to find them. And they might call out

372.84.text:
and wave to you, and you still haven't got
a clue where they are. Or trying to find someone

379.18.text:
in a crowd for instance, just trying to pick
out a face is virtually impossible. Or even

384.22.text:
if someone just walks straight past me and
says hello, I won't see their face quickly

389.21.text:
enough to register who it was. So unless I
happen to recognise their voice, or they have

392.21.text:
something really distinctive about their appearance
that always makes me recognise them, sometimes

397.37.text:
I'll appear to blank people. So that can be
a bit awkward sometimes.

403.08.text:
And then I can't always judge people's facial
expressions either. I don't always look people

409.39.text:
directly in the eyes, because I know if I
was to try and, like, force myself to look

415.68.text:
at someone in the eyes, it would be a strain,
kind of, on the Nystagmus in my eyes and make

421.05.text:
that a bit worse. It's better to let my eyes
kind of do whatever they're gonna do, rather

425.62.text:
than try and force them to stick in place,
because I can't do that. So yeah, I tend to

431.24.text:
just make sure I'm facing in the person's
direction. And, like I say, I can't always

437.62.text:
judge their expressions or the looks in their
eyes to always accurately gauge how they're

441.70.text:
feeling. Usually there's other cues as well,
but occasionally you can't always tell.

445.55.text:
And likewise even with me, because my eyes
don't look normal, sometimes people misinterpret

453.27.text:
how I'm feeling as well. You know, they might
think I'm upset or angry when I'm really not.

457.33.text: You know, something like that. It's just little things that people pick up on that they might misinterpret.

464.48.text:
And then the other thing is that when I'm
in a noisy environment, like a busy pub or

468.98.text:
something like that, sometimes it's hard to
pick out people's voices in amongst all the

473.29.text:
noise. You know, if there's a couple of people
opposite me or next to me having a conversation,

476.47.text:
and I kind of want to listen in to chip in,
it's a little bit hard sometimes if they're

481.17.text:
not talking to me directly, to pick up their
voices if there's lots of other extraneous

486.39.text: noise, like music and other people shouting and talking away. So yeah, that can be quite difficult.

493.31.text:
I know there is an associated condition with
Aniridia called Auditory Processing Disorder,

498.37.text:
which I think I might have an element of from
what i've read about it, having edited a presentation

503.47.text:
about it for the Aniridia Network's channel.
I mean, I don't know, I'm not a doctor, but

508.61.text:
it sounds like the sort of thing that I might
have some aspect of. It's not a case of my

513.42.text:
hearing being bad, my hearing itself is fine,
but it's the way my brain processes it. I

518.37.text:
think it's all part of the genetic defect
I have that gave me Aniridia, I think it's

522.87.text:
kind of connected. So yeah, that can be quite
hard. Noisy, busy environments can be quite

531.34.text:
Question 4 - What's the best part about being
blind or visually impaired?

536.20.text:
It does have its perks. I'd say discounted
or free travel is quite a big perk, and not

541.79.text:
having to own a car. I don't have to pay insurance
or for petrol or the MOTs on the car, and

549.67.text:
things like that. So that's a huge cost deduction
in itself. Certainly here in London you don't

554.94.text:
drive if you can really help it I don't think.
And then I have a Disabled Person's Railcard,

560.05.text:
so that gets me a third off. I had concessionary
bus travel i.e. free bus travel where I came

566.74.text:
from, and I'm hoping to get the same here.
We're just kind of looking into that at the

571.63.text:
moment, signing up-with the local authority
and all the rest of it. So hopefully I might

575.60.text:
be able to get a free Oyster card for free
travel. But we'll see.

580.05.text:
But yeah, I like using public transport. The
Tube and the buses here are easy to use. Especially

587.56.text:
now you've got smartphone apps as well like
Citymapper and Street View and things. I can

592.04.text:
plan my journey in advance really easily,
so I know where I'm going before I get there,

597.75.text:
which is a lot easier than it ever used to
be in years gone by. So I think at the moment

603.37.text:
we live in a really good time where it's much
easier to find your way around, as long as

609.92.text:
you get used to the apps and things that you
can get, and things like that. There's a lot

613.91.text:
of help out there. So yeah, I'd say free travel,
or discounted travel, is very, very helpful,

622.02.text:
and definitely helps me to be more independent
and confident. I like that a lot.

627.25.text:
Question 5 - What question do you get asked
about or because of your vision?

632.69.text:
Do glasses help? That's the number one question
everybody wants to ask, and often does ask.

639.21.text:
I suppose it is a natural thing to wonder,
but then if you pause for a second and think

645.23.text:
about it, you know, if glasses helped, then
I would be wearing them, it's as simple as

650.63.text:
that. I have tried various lenses in the past,
they haven't helped, and I've managed fine

656.48.text:
without them so far. You know, if it got to
a point where I did need glasses, I'd be prepared

660.69.text:
to wear them. But so far so good. Sunglasses
are the only things I wear, but otherwise,

668.46.text:
yeah, I get by without glasses. It's just
fine like that, you know.

674.56.text:
And I know the question is well-intentioned,
so I'm not knocking anyone who asks it. But

679.05.text:
if you ever feel like asking me that question,
the simple answer is no, glasses don't help,

684.71.text: yes I have tried them. I don't feel I need them so, yeah, I don't need glasses at the moment.

690.86.text:
Question 6 - Do you have a cane, a guide dog,
or neither?

694.75.text:
Neither in my case. Like glasses, I don't
feel I need a cane or a guide dog either.

699.93.text:
I've developed enough independence to get
around by myself. I was trained to use a symbol

705.28.text:
cane in school, a white cane, but I never
continued with it after I left. I just didn't

711.85.text:
feel I needed it. Again, if my sight were
to get worse in the future, and it may well

716.50.text:
do - hopefully not for a long time if it's
gonna happen at all, but if it does - then,

721.76.text:
yeah, I will consider the options as necessary.
I'll consider a cane, I'll consider a guide

726.06.text:
dog, whatever is gonna be best for me. So,
yeah, at the moment I don't need those things,

731.89.text:
but in the future I would be happy to consider
them accordingly if need be.

736.84.text:
Question 7 - What piece of advice would you
give to someone who is going to lose, or is

741.83.text: losing, or has completely lost their vision?

744.60.text:
It's not the end of the world, it won't stop
you living your life. I think that's the thing

748.48.text:
I would say. It will be a knock to your confidence,
and it will take quite a bit of time and effort

754.75.text:
to adjust and adapt to how things are going.
But there is a lot of help and support out

760.05.text:
there now - make sure you get it, make sure
you have your family and friends around you,

765.35.text:
and just work at it bit by bit, and just adapt
to it as best you can. Don't think about what

770.12.text:
you can't do, because there are a lot of things
you can do, you'd be surprised.

773.90.text:
You know, there are a lot of things that,
just by adapting how you do things and doing

779.56.text:
things differently, it is still possible to
do a lot of the things that you love and enjoy.

784.03.text:
I mean there's a friend of mine, at the extreme
level, who does extreme sports. But, you know,

788.81.text:
it can just be something simple like, I don't
know, learning an instrument or something,

792.90.text:
there's plenty of blind musicians out there.
Or there's plenty of sports out there you

796.18.text:
can do. You know, visually impaired people
can still play tennis, they can still play

799.78.text:
goalball, they can still swimming and running,
things like that. Or whatever your hobbies

805.84.text:
may be, in a lot of cases you'll still be
able to do it.

809.89.text:
Ok, you might not be able to drive or things
like that, but, you know, don't think about

814.36.text:
the can'ts, think about the cans. There are
lots of things you can do. Research it, look

819.40.text:
into it, you'd be surprised. Especially with
the internet these days, you know, with all

823.73.text:
the social media and Google and everything
else, there's a lot of information out there.

828.45.text:
So, yeah, don't think you can't do something.
Check it out first, you never know.

834.87.text:
And then just take your time, do it bit by
bit. It will take a while, it will be frustrating

839.84.text:
sometimes. But like I say, it's not the end
of the world. If you just keep taking things

844.91.text:
step by step, day by day, you will grow in
confidence, you will grow in independence,

850.52.text:
and you will be fine. So just don't give up
on it if it seems to be taking a while. You

855.80.text: will get there, it will be fine.

858.18.text:
Question 8 - What one piece of advice would
you give to a sighted person who is interacting

862.40.text: with someone who is blind or visually impaired?

866.21.text:
Don't make assumptions, don't make judgements.
Don't think you know what that person is going

871.04.text:
through. because you don't. You may have met
people who are blind or visually impaired

876.14.text:
before, you may even have met people with
the exact same condition that this other person

880.11.text:
has. But every person is different, every
person with a disability is different. And

886.93.text:
the effects of even the same disability differs
across people, depending on how they've adapted

891.89.text:
to it, depending on severe it is. There are
so many variables at play, you really cannot

897.74.text:
assume anything. So don't try and guess. The
only person who truly understand how their

903.53.text:
disability affects them is the disabled person
themselves.

906.28.text:
All you need to do is just be yourself, be
respectful. Offer to help them if they need

912.93.text:
it, and if they don't need the help, don't
force it upon them. And if you want to ask

917.68.text:
about their disability, ask if it's ok to
do so, and just try and be sensible with the

922.43.text:
questions. Don't be too intrusive. You know,
it's flattering that you're interested, and

929.24.text:
it's great and, you know, often we don't mind
you asking questions. We're happy to help

933.82.text:
you learn and understand things, that's fine.
It's just a case of being respectful, that's

939.53.text:
all. That's all you need to do - just be yourself
and be nice. Simple as that.

944.38.text: Question 9 - Why did you join Youtube?

947.52.text:
I joined as an experiment really, it was a
bit of a whim in a way. I knew that, because

954.98.text:
I was coming up to London eventually, I knew
I'd have to start making some connections

961.15.text:
and, you know, just seeking out resources
and things like that. Not necessarily making

965.79.text:
friends online, but just seeking out information
and resources and things like that that might

971.39.text:
And then I came across bloggers like Emily
Davison and Molly Burke and Tommy Edison and

979.02.text:
My Blurred World and all sorts of other people.
I could name people forever and I'll miss

983.17.text:
people out. And I realised that there was
this whole community of visually impaired

986.28.text:
people out there talking about their conditions
and raising awareness. And I thought, yeah,

990.71.text:
you know, that would be nice to get involved
in. But I was really nervous about it, I mean,

995.38.text: it's not something that I've ever done before.

998.74.text:
So, you know, I kind of was looking for a
way in. And then Scope did their End The Awkward

1006.78.text:
campaign one year, and I quickly knocked out
a video for that. I'll link to that in the

1013.53.text:
description as well. It was just done very
quickly, just like this, just holding my phone

1020.06.text:
up, just recording it. I didn't think it was
great, but people seemed to like it. That

1026.32.text:
wasn't the start of regular videos, it was
just an experiment to see how that went.

1031.17.text:
And then, a few months later, I decided to
start up a written blog, because I found it

1037.39.text:
more comfortable perhaps to start actually
writing things, where I can edit it properly

1042.47.text:
and really think about what I'm saying. I
think I'm more of a writer than a speaker

1048.19.text:
really. So I kind of focused on the written
blog for a while.

1053.17.text:
And then, after doing that for a bit, I realised
that those blogs could be adapted into scripts,

1058.58.text:
and if I combine with, like, photos and video
clips I've already got, I could kind of use

1065.93.text:
the scripts to create a voiceover, and create
some hopefully interesting videos about my

1071.76.text:
condition. And so I started having a go at
that, and that worked well. I mean, I haven't

1079.29.text:
got millions of viewers, but it generated
interest, and it got good feedback from the

1083.88.text:
people that did see it. So I kind of just
carried it on a bit.

1087.00.text:
And then it's kind of gone in the other direction
a little bit, in that as I've kind of continued

1093.95.text:
just knocking out videos and blog posts here
and there, I've now got to a point where I'm

1102.29.text:
making videos, and then posting the transcripts
of those videos in the blog. So the videos

1106.56.text:
are becoming blog posts, rather than the blog
posts becoming videos. It's kind of becoming

1109.53.text:
a mixture of the two now. So yeah, that's
quite useful.

1115.14.text:
The transcripts come from the fact that I'm
captioning all my videos. I've been captioning

1121.34.text:
some of Emily Davison's as well, as a favour
to her because she does very good work, and

1127.84.text:
I've been captioning my own as well in the
process. So the transcripts I've been typing

1132.17.text:
up for myself, I've been able to put in the
blog to make extra posts. So yeah, it's kind

1137.12.text:
of developed. I haven't got any major plans
for what to do with the channel or the blog,

1141.72.text:
I'm just kind of posting things as I feel
like it, in the hope that people will be interested

1148.24.text:
in it. You know, like I say, I'm not after
lots of ad revenue, I'm not trying to be a

1154.48.text:
big Youtube sensation or anything like that.
I'm just putting stuff out there, and if it

1158.53.text:
interests people, great. if it doesn't, that's
fine too.

1162.07.text:
So yeah, it's worked out well. And through
it I've made a few useful connections, I think

1167.39.text:
that's the key thing. I've made a few good
friends. And, you know, there are even people

1172.39.text:
that I'm looking to meet up with. There's
one person in a couple of days time I'm meeting

1176.65.text:
up with, as a direct result of them seeing
the stuff I've done on here, and then I've

1180.82.text:
helped them with a few of their videos as
well. So yeah, I'm glad I've done it, it's

1185.66.text:
been an interesting and a worthwhile experiment
I think. It's been something new for me, completely

1192.60.text: new. And, yeah, it's paid dividends, it's had outcomes, so I'm very happy I've done it.

1198.50.text: And I will keep doing little bits here and there, to keep it going, keep it ticking over.

1203.88.text:
Question 10 - Name 3 people to do this tag
next.

1207.16.text:
I don't really know who to suggest for this,
because the bloggers and Youtubers that I

1214.58.text:
follow, the names that I would have in mind
have already done it, either in written form

1218.75.text:
or in video form. So I'm not really sure who
I can easily nominate amongst the people who

1225.99.text: I know read or watch my content.

1228.54.text:
So I'll basically just say if you're watching
this, and you want to do this tag, please

1234.22.text:
feel free. Credit Chatty Chelby for creating
the tag in the first place. And let me know

1239.54.text:
if you do the tag as well as a result of watching
this.

1242.45.text:
But I hope you found my answers interesting,
I know I'm a bit of a rambler sometimes. But,

1248.27.text:
yeah, I hope it gave you a little insight
into how things go for me. There are other

1254.10.text:
videos on my channel where I go into more
detail about some of this stuff, so if you

1257.27.text:
haven't seen them, by all means go and watch
them. If you have any questions, leave them

1260.40.text:
in the comments. If there's any videos you
want me to do, talking about certain things,

1264.65.text:
again let me know in the comments. Or on Twitter
I'm at well_eye_never. My blog is at welleyenever.com.

1272.74.text:
And the word 'eye' in the middle, not the
letter 'i', it's the word 'eye', E-Y-E.

1278.19.text:
And that's it, yeah, so again, thank you Chatty
Chelby for creating the tag,

1284.03.text:
thank you to Emily Davison for tagging me to do it, and
thank you for watching,

1289.33.text: I hope you found it interesting. Bye for now.
